Comment:
Hi everyone!

Here is another game in Concordborn's Sicilian Pelikan MT.  It has a lot of twists and turns to it and both sides made big blunders.  These blunders thankfully proved not to be fatal for either side, although it did result in me conceding a low draw in the endgame.  At least my opponent is a fellow Class A player, and if a load of Experts and Masters had not timed out on me, Tamas and I would have had similar ratings.  So, how did this latest drama unfold?  Well, to follow this game, the Gameknot Analysis link is as follows:- http://gameknot.com/analyze-board.pl?bd=17836218&rnd=0.45445301136640437

15. Qh5 - Whoohoo, woohoo, out comes Glenda on her broomstick to h5.  She is putting f7 and h7 under her beady eye and the pawn on f5 is now doubly attacked.  Tamas screens off this attack with e4 next turn.

16. ...... 0-0 - Tamas now tucks his king away, can I launch a mating attack on his castled king?  It may take a long job with the centre fixed with black pawns but maybe a rook lift from a1-e1 - h3 or g3 could be an idea.  I execute it later on, only to be bogged down by Old Matey patrolling my back row.

27. Bxg6?? - OMG - I should have played Rf2 skewering the Witch and the rook on a2.  The only thing was, and this is something to beware of, especially when you are playing a lot of games with problematical moves to think about, it can be sooo easy to switch off from a game where your opponent takes a few days to make a move.  When you come back to the board, even though you may have calculated the correct move, it can be easy to go wrong.  Lesson 2 - if you do put it in your notes, check your notes every time you are about to make your move.  It may prevent you from making Yours Truly's mistake.

28. Qf6+ - nothing for it but to go for all out attack and hope that it will lead to mate for black.
28. Qf6+ - nothing for it but to go for all out attack and hope that it will lead to mate for black.

29. Rg3 - continuing in the attempt to redeem myself.  The threat here is Rxg6+ as the f7 pawn is pinned to the rook on f8 and my rook on f1 can then join in the attack on the denuded BK after Glenda removes the rook on f8 with check.  I would have liked to have played Rh3 here (threatening Rh8#), but after seeing a grinning Old Matey point his skeletal like finger towards g2 that move is out of the question, sigh and double sigh!

30. Qxd6 - might as well reduce my material deficit to only one point which should have been a lead of 3 points.

31. Qxa3 - reducing it to zero - again, should have been plus 4.
31. Qxa3 - reducing it to zero - again, should have been plus 4.

32. Qxa6 - Glenda removes the final passer on the queenside.  I am now up in material and at least I have a potential Glenda 2 on the d column.  But will that potential be realised?  We shall see.  Note that that capture on a6 was only possible because Glenda (known as Glenda the Defender), poor put upon lady, defends the rook on f1.
